items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 01:45 AM on 10/09/2021.
Areas most at risk include Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stannah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stannah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods at 01:45 AM on 10/09/2021. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
After this tideâ€š the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
We will remove this message by 09:00 AM on 10/09/2021.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This flood alert has been removed as the risk of overtopping waves and spray has now passed.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Waves are forecast to overtop sea defences as a result of high tides.  First forecast high water is 21:15 on 08/09/21 with a level of 7.34 mAOD, wind Force 2, in a westerly direction. Second forecast high water is 22:00 on 09/09/21 with a level of 7.46 mAOD, wind Force 3, in a southwesterly direction. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth.. Flooding to roads and properties is possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of high tide.
Coastal conditions are expected to continue until after the high tides at 22:30 on 10/09/21 at Pill and Shirehampton.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads and consider installing property flood resilience equipment.  
This message will be updated Thursday, 09/09/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond will be 4.60mAOD at 17:15 on 09/09/21 and 4.48mAOD at 06:00 on 10/09/21.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 20 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 12:00 on 10/09/21, or as the situation changes.

Waves are expected to affect the foreshore as a result of high spring tides. Flooding of low lying coastal paths, roads and farmland is possible tonight, between midnight and 04:00 am tomorrow morning, Friday 10th September 2021. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land, roads and coastal paths at Roosebeck, South Ulverston, Canal Foot, Crake estuary, Rusland Valley, Leven estuary, Eea estuary, Flookburgh, East Plain Farm, Grange-over-Sands, Meathop, Kent estuary, Milnthorpe, B5282 coast road, Sandside and Arnside. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths and roads along the coastline. Subsequent tides are not currently forecast to reach the Flood Alert threshold. This message will be updated by 10:00 am on Friday 10th September, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Thursday evening. High water at Ilfracombe is at 8.37pm, times of high water will vary along the coast.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe is 5.05 mAOD, this is 0.21 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: River Spen and Batley Beck catchments

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Spen, Batley Beck, Chickenley Beck

items.message:
River levels on the River Spen and Batley Beck are now falling after the heavy thunderstorms this afternoon. The showers and thunderstorms should gradually die away later this evening and overnight. Showers on Friday may lead to some further flooding impacts but are not currently expected to be as heavy as those seen in some areas today. 
We continue to monitor the situation closely.  For weather forecasts for your area please see the Met
Office www.metoffice.gov.uk.

items.description: Wyke Beck, Meanwood Beck and Wortley Beck catchments

floodArea.riverOrSea: Wyke Beck, Meanwood Beck, Wortley Beck

items.message:
Thunderstorms and heavy showers this afternoon only led to a small response from local watercourses and the showers and thunderstorms should gradually die away later this evening and overnight. Showers on Friday may lead to some further flooding impacts but are not currently expected to be as heavy as those seen in some areas today. 
We continue to monitor the situation closely.  For weather forecasts for your area please see the Met
Office www.metoffice.gov.uk.

The first forecast high water is 09:45 on 10/09/21 with a level of 6.29 mAOD and a Force 4 Westerly wind. Second forecast high water is 22:00 on 10/09/21 with a level of 6.34 mAOD and a Force 4 Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley, mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. Flooding may occur along the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Coastal conditions should ease from Saturday 11/09/21 high tide at 10:30 and all subsequent high tides.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates.  
This message will be updated if the situation changes.
